image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Qantas' board is under enormous pressure to scrap Alan Joyce's final payout. Could they actually do it?

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe is giving his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while the ASX is trading down after poor US economic data prompted concerns interest rates will stay higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Lowe admits RBA 'did too much' when it came to interest rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "During my term, there have been times where monetary and fiscal policy worked very closely together and, at other times, it would be an exaggeration to say this was the case," he says. "The coordination was most effective during the pandemic. During that period, fiscal policy was nimble and the political constraints on its use for stabilisation purposes faded away. " And we saw just how powerful it can be when the government and RBA work very closely together. "There are some broader lessons here and I was disappointed that the recent RBA Review did not explore them in more depth."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lowe would like to see the RBA and government work together more

children.content: "During my term, there have been times where monetary and fiscal policy worked very closely together and, at other times, it would be an exaggeration to say this was the case," he says.
"The coordination was most effective during the pandemic. During that period, fiscal policy was nimble and the political constraints on its use for stabilisation purposes faded away.
" And we saw just how powerful it can be when the government and RBA work very closely together.
"There are some broader lessons here and I was disappointed that the recent RBA Review did not explore them in more depth."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He has moved onto fiscal policy framework, and the need for ongoing infrastructure investment. "Australia’s growing population means that we need to keep investing in public assets," he said. "Some years ago, I spoke about my concerns that we were not doing enough here, partly due to governments seeking to avoid taking on debt. "More recently, my concern has been that we were seeking to do too much, in too short a time. "A well-established framework, based on rigorous independent cost-benefit analysis, would help the country plan and sequence public investment. "It would also lower risk premiums on private-sector investments and give the public greater confidence that money was being spent wisely."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More infrastructure is needed to encourage economic growth, Lowe says

children.content: He has moved onto fiscal policy framework, and the need for ongoing infrastructure investment.
"Australia’s growing population means that we need to keep investing in public assets," he said.
"Some years ago, I spoke about my concerns that we were not doing enough here, partly due to governments seeking to avoid taking on debt.
"More recently, my concern has been that we were seeking to do too much, in too short a time.
"A well-established framework, based on rigorous independent cost-benefit analysis, would help the country plan and sequence public investment.
"It would also lower risk premiums on private-sector investments and give the public greater confidence that money was being spent wisely."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Lowe continues on the recent criticisms of the RBA. "With the benefit of hindsight, my view is that we did do too much ," he says. "But hindsight is a wonderful thing. None of us can predict the future and we have had to make decisions under great uncertainty and with incomplete information. "We got some things right, but we got other things wrong. "I can assure you, though, that the staff of the RBA and members of the Reserve Bank Board have been relentless in their pursuit of doing the right thing and supporting the economic prosperity of the people of Australia. "And I will leave the RBA after 43 years proud of our contribution to the stability of both our economy and financial system."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We did too much', Lowe admits over RBA's response to pandemic and interest rates

children.content: Lowe continues on the recent criticisms of the RBA.
my view is that we did do too much
"But hindsight is a wonderful thing. None of us can predict the future and we have had to make decisions under great uncertainty and with incomplete information.
"We got some things right, but we got other things wrong.

"I can assure you, though, that the staff of the RBA and members of the Reserve Bank Board have been relentless in their pursuit of doing the right thing and supporting the economic prosperity of the people of Australia.
"And I will leave the RBA after 43 years proud of our contribution to the stability of both our economy and financial system."

image.altText: A group of men wearing suits

items.synopsis: Police allege the 61-year-old concealed a serious indictable offence after the incident on Friday night, where two people were killed in Sydney's south-west.

title.children: Alleged driver's father charged with hindering investigation into fatal Heckenberg crash

image.altText: UFC Middleweight title contender Sean Strickland at Sydney holding a microphone with NSW government logo beside him

items.synopsis: NSW sports minister says a whole sport can't be tarnished by "one or two people" after comments by controversial mixed martial arts fighter Sean Strickland ahead of the government-funded event.

title.children: NSW premier labels UFC fighter's sexist comments 'appalling' ahead of taxpayer-funded Sydney bout

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing rainfall anomaly patterns, mostly red to indicate dryness. A date indicates August 2023

items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: Forecast chart showing blue over Great Australian Bight and SA, polar air mass heading for country's south-east

items.synopsis: It was a sunny start to the week but from today a polar air mass will sweep over south-east Australia, causing temperatures to plummet by as much as 15 degrees Celsius in 24 hours.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: Catherine King says the 2020 incident was one factor in her decision to reject Qatar's application to increase its flights to major Australian airports, but that no single issue swayed her one way or the other.

title.children: 'Absolute nonsense': Transport minister rejects claims Qatar flights would make big difference to ticket prices

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

image.altText: An aerial view of houses with red roofs and a big tree in the middle.

image.altText: A pristine-looking river perfectly mirroring the sky.

items.synopsis: The men, both aged 73, were expected to return from their trip last night.

title.children: Body found in search for pair of fishermen missing in Snowy Mountains

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: More than 400 medicines are in 'short supply' in Australia. Advocates are calling for change

image.altText: A man in a dark corner putting his hands on a red brick wall and his feet on the opposite white wall floating above ground

image.altText: three men at sea.

items.synopsis: Australian Border Force officers have greeted three sailors who had to be rescued from a sinking catamaran in the Coral Sea.

image.altText: a small shark out of water

image.altText: a baby maugean skate in front of a light, looks translucent and glows red

items.synopsis: The maugean skate, a species of ray, is only found in one waterway and it is thought there are fewer than 1,000 left.

title.children: It may not have the friendliest face, but $2.1m has just been spent to save it

image.altText: A woman crouching looking up at a furry animal and patting it as its held by another person.

image.altText: A car is engulfed in flames in the bush.

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie standing outside

title.children: New mega-hospital on greenfields site for Albury Wodonga off the table

image.altText: Newcastle MP tim crakanthorp standing in NSW Parliament. He is giving a speech to the House.

image.altText: A dam and rolling green hills.

title.children: The classic farm dam could be capable of generating 30 kilowatt hours of power

image.altText: Person holds woman who is emotional behind them is debris of homes

image.altText: A woman stands at a table outside surrounded by buckets of pink and white Geraldton Wax flowers.

items.synopsis: Planting flowers in the middle of a drought doesn't seem like the obvious choice to diversify but this family has said goodbye to sheep and hello to hundreds of Geraldton wax plants.

title.children: In a horrible drought, Allie turned to flower growing and now her blooms sell out within the hour
